newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Samsung tables Fokker rescue plan.
newsitem.headline: Samsung tables Fokker rescue plan.

text.p: South Korea's Samsung Aerospace made a concrete proposal for a relaunch of bankrupt planemaker Fokker Tuesday when it handed over a long-awaited business plan to the Dutch Economics Ministry.
A large delegation of Samsung officials and Fokker receivers arrived early in the afternoon in The Hague, where they presented their plan, a ministry spokesman said.

Samsung is asking the government to take a minority stake in the new Fokker and to provide large sums of money in straight subsidies, but neither Fokker nor the Ministry would give any further details.
"The plan has just arrived. We'll study it carefully and then formulate a reaction," the spokesman said.
The planemaker collapsed under a mountain of debt and went bankrupt on March 15, two months after its German parent Daimler Benz Aerospace cut a vital cash lifeline.

The firm has since been kept alive artificially by its court-appointed receivers. It has even accepted orders for new aircraft to preserve the value of its assets. But a structural rescue is needed before the end of the month.
"We told the (Fokker) workers on Friday that the deadline for a possible rescue is at the end of October," said Ben Knueppe, spokesman for the receivers.

A rescue hinges on whether the Dutch government is prepared to invest tax-payers' money in a relaunch. The Fokker receivers and Samsung have a common interest and have already settled most outstanding issues, said a source close to the negotiations.

A successful resuscitation depends on three factors -- the purchasing sum, the establishment of a new aircraft leasing company and, most importantly, loans to develop a new 125-seat aircraft, he said, quoting work documents for the business plan.

The South Koreans have put great emphasis on a new, larger aircraft, capable of carrying more passengers than Fokker's current line of 50-, 70- and 100-seat jets. Fokker's work documents estimate the development costs of a new 125-seat aircraft at roughly 700 million guilders ($409.1 million).
This amount could be increased by 500 million guilders ($292 million) if it were decided to revamp the F70 and F100 jetliners, extending their life cycle beyond 2010.
If Samsung and the Dutch government strike a deal before the end-October deadline, jobs at the F70 and F100 assembly lines will be safe for the remaining life of these planes.
Most of the design and engineering work on the new 125-seat jet will also be done in the Netherlands but it will be built in South Korea, the source said.
